comment_text.mn101:1.2: Devadaha also appears in SN 22.2 and SN 35.134. The name is explained in the commentary as “royal lake”, taking deva- as a term for kings, and -daha as equivalent to the Sanskrit hrada, “lake”. However it is spelled devadṛśa in the Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya (San Mu Kd 17:16). Dṛśa means “sight, appearance”, thus occupying a completely different semantic space than “lake”. It is a Vedic term that commonly describes Agni’s fiery gleam (Rig Veda 3.17.4, 6.10.4, 7.1.1, etc.). This suggests a Pali derivation from √ḍah, “to burn”. This in turn recalls Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.4.1.14, which allegorically depicts the spread of Aryan culture eastward as Agni “burning” (dadāha) the lands, i.e. introducing the civilized practice of Vedic fire worship. I think the meaning of devadaha is, therefore, “burned by the god”, or “place of the god’s flame”. It became famous in later Buddhism as the birthplace of the sisters Māyā and Mahāpajāpatī of the Koliyan clan, the Buddha’s birth mother and foster mother. These details are not mentioned in early texts, however, where the town is said to be Sakyan rather than Koliyan. It is identified with Devdaha in the Rupandehi District of Nepal.
comment_text.mn101:2.5: The view that all experiences are caused by past kamma is consistently rejected in the suttas (eg. AN 3.61:2.1, SN 36.21). This is reflected in the later Theravada commentaries, which describe five interacting niyāmas, or systems of natural law: seasons (utu), genetics (bīja), moral or immoral deeds (kamma), mind (citta), and principles of the teaching (dhamma). Nonetheless, the view that all experiences are caused by kamma is extremely common among modern Buddhists, and is often heard even from learned scholars. This is a harmful misunderstanding, as it has led to discrimination against the poor and disabled in Buddhist countries. One point of confusion is that rebirth into a particular life is caused by kamma, so in that general sense, kamma is a necessary condition for having a life in which one can experience anything. But the feelings experienced in that life are caused by a variety of things, not necessarily by kamma. | Note the use of purisapuggala (“individual person”) as a Jain idiom. See MN 35:10.7 and note, and SN 22.22 and notes.
comment_text.mn101:2.6: Jains believed that karma was material, made up of particles. The practice of tapas (“fervent mortification”) creates an intense bodily heat which burns off these karmic particles, freeing the soul (jīva) to shine in its intrinsic purity. | This passage also at MN 14:17.7.
comment_text.mn101:2.7: The mention of “feeling” after “suffering” here is found consistently in Pali sources, but not in their parallels. | Nijiṇṇa (“worn away”) is a characteristic Jain term that is sometimes applied to kamma in the suttas as well.
comment_text.mn101:2.8: The idea that the elimination of karma leads to freedom from suffering is indeed a fundamental tenet of Jain thought.
comment_text.mn101:15.3: This is a difficult sentence, and different translators handle it in quite different ways. I take vipaccetha as second plural optative, intended as a rhetorical question. The sense, I think, plays on the common meaning of “ripen”, but in the sense “make something out of it that it isn’t”, i.e. (mis)construe.
comment_text.mn101:16.2: Just as different deeds have differing characteristics, the results of those deeds also have different characteristics, which constrain the result in certain ways. This does not mean that they are fully deterministic, however. Compare the sprouting of a seed. A mango seed cannot give rise to an orange tree. And it has certain conditions under which it cannot sprout—if it is out of season, or the soil is inadequate, or there is no water, etc. Still, there are many different ways that it can sprout, and the tree and its fruit that result will vary according to conditions.
comment_text.mn101:20.3: This is a deed that has no opportunity to bear fruit, like a good seed on barren soil.
comment_text.mn101:22.2: The “ten legitimate grounds” are, as explained below, the five grounds and their inversions. Whether or not the ground is true, the Jains deserve censure.
comment_text.mn101:22.5: “God Almighty” is issara, the creator deity. See also AN 3.61.
comment_text.mn101:22.7: This is the Ājīvika doctrine of the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla, for which see DN 2:20.6, MN 60:21.7, and AN 3.61. The mention of Ājīvika doctrines here and in the next section reflect their closeness with the Jains.
comment_text.mn101:22.9: See AN 6.57 for a fuller discussion of this Ājīvika doctrine.

comment_text.mn101:23.2: Literally, a mendicant “does not oppress the unoppressed self with suffering”. For addhabhūta see SN 35.29.

root_text.mn101:15.1: Yasmā ca kho, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yasmiṁ vo samaye tibbo upakkamo hoti tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;
root_text.mn101:15.2: yasmiṁ pana vo samaye na tibbo upakkamo hoti na tibbaṁ padhānaṁ, na tibbā tasmiṁ samaye opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyetha;
root_text.mn101:15.3: te tumhe sāmaṁyeva opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vedayamānā avijjā aññāṇā sammohā vipaccetha:
root_text.mn101:15.4: “yaṁ kiñcāyaṁ purisapuggalo paṭisaṁvedeti sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ pubbekatahetu.
root_text.mn101:15.5: Iti purāṇānaṁ kammānaṁ tapasā byantībhāvā, navānaṁ kammānaṁ akaraṇā, āyatiṁ anavassavo;
root_text.mn101:15.6: āyatiṁ anavassavā kammakkhayo; kammakkhayā dukkhakkhayo; dukkhakkhayā vedanākkhayo; vedanākkhayā sabbaṁ dukkhaṁ nijjiṇṇaṁ bhavissatī”’ti.
root_text.mn101:15.7: Evaṁvādīpi kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhesu na kañci sahadhammikaṁ vādapaṭihāraṁ samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn101:16.1: Puna caparāhaṁ, bhikkhave, te nigaṇṭhe evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.mn101:16.2: ‘taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā samparāyavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:16.4: ‘Yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ samparāyavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:17.1: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ sukhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā dukkhavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:17.3: ‘Yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā sukhavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:18.1: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ paripakkavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā aparipakkavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:18.3: ‘Yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ aparipakkavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā paripakkavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:19.1: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ bahuvedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā appavedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:19.3: ‘Yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ appavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā bahuvedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:20.1: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññathāvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ savedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā avedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:20.3: ‘Yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ avedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā savedanīyaṁ hotūti labbhametan’ti?
root_text.mn101:21.1: ‘Iti kira, āvuso nigaṇṭhā, yamidaṁ kammaṁ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā samparāyavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yaṁ panidaṁ kammaṁ samparāyavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ sukhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā dukkhavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā sukhavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ paripakkavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā aparipakkavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ aparipakkavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā paripakkavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ bahuvedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā appavedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ appavedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā bahuvedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ savedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā avedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ, yamidaṁ kammaṁ avedanīyaṁ taṁ upakkamena vā padhānena vā savedanīyaṁ hotūti alabbhametaṁ;
root_text.mn101:21.2: evaṁ sante āyasmantānaṁ nigaṇṭhānaṁ aphalo upakkamo hoti, aphalaṁ padhānaṁ’.
root_text.mn101:22.2: Evaṁvādīnaṁ, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhānaṁ dasa sahadhammikā vādānuvādā gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgacchanti.
root_text.mn101:22.3: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti;
root_text.mn101:22.4: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pubbe dukkaṭakammakārino yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
root_text.mn101:22.5: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā issaranimmānahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti;
root_text.mn101:22.6: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpakena issarena nimmitā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
root_text.mn101:22.7: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā saṅgatibhāvahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti;
root_text.mn101:22.8: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpasaṅgatikā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
root_text.mn101:22.9: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā abhijātihetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti;
root_text.mn101:22.10: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā pāpābhijātikā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
root_text.mn101:22.11: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti;
root_text.mn101:22.12: addhā, bhikkhave, nigaṇṭhā evarūpā diṭṭhadhammūpakkamā yaṁ etarahi evarūpā dukkhā tibbā kaṭukā vedanā vediyanti.
root_text.mn101:22.13: Sace, bhikkhave, sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā;
root_text.mn101:22.14: no ce sattā pubbekatahetu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti, gārayhā nigaṇṭhā.

root_text.mn101:23.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ?
root_text.mn101:23.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva anaddhabhūtaṁ attānaṁ dukkhena addhabhāveti, dhammikañca sukhaṁ na pariccajati, tasmiñca sukhe anadhimucchito hoti.
root_text.mn101:23.4: ‘imassa kho me dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, imassa pana me dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hotī’ti.
root_text.mn101:23.5: So yassa hi khvāssa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, saṅkhāraṁ tattha padahati.
root_text.mn101:23.6: Yassa panassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti, upekkhaṁ tattha bhāveti.
root_text.mn101:23.7: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti—
root_text.mn101:23.9: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti—
root_text.mn101:24.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso itthiyā sāratto paṭibaddhacitto tibbacchando tibbāpekkho.
root_text.mn101:24.2: So taṁ itthiṁ passeyya aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ.
root_text.mn101:24.4: api nu tassa purisassa amuṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti?
root_text.mn101:24.7: “Amu hi, bhante, puriso amussā itthiyā sāratto paṭibaddhacitto tibbacchando tibbāpekkho.
root_text.mn101:24.8: Tasmā taṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti.
root_text.mn101:25.2: ‘ahaṁ kho amussā itthiyā sāratto paṭibaddhacitto tibbacchando tibbāpekkho.
root_text.mn101:25.3: Tassa me amuṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā.
root_text.mn101:25.4: Yannūnāhaṁ yo me amussā itthiyā chandarāgo taṁ pajaheyyan’ti.
root_text.mn101:25.5: So yo amussā itthiyā chandarāgo taṁ pajaheyya.
root_text.mn101:25.6: So taṁ itthiṁ passeyya aparena samayena aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ.
root_text.mn101:25.8: api nu tassa purisassa amuṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti?
root_text.mn101:25.11: “Amu hi, bhante, puriso amussā itthiyā virāgo.
root_text.mn101:25.12: Tasmā taṁ itthiṁ disvā aññena purisena saddhiṁ santiṭṭhantiṁ sallapantiṁ sañjagghantiṁ saṁhasantiṁ na uppajjeyyuṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassūpāyāsā”ti.
root_text.mn101:26.1: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva anaddhabhūtaṁ attānaṁ dukkhena addhabhāveti, dhammikañca sukhaṁ na pariccajati, tasmiñca sukhe anadhimucchito hoti.
root_text.mn101:26.3: ‘imassa kho me dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, imassa pana me dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hotī’ti.
root_text.mn101:26.4: So yassa hi khvāssa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti, saṅkhāraṁ tattha padahati;
root_text.mn101:26.5: yassa panassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti, upekkhaṁ tattha bhāveti.
root_text.mn101:26.6: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa saṅkhāraṁ padahato saṅkhārappadhānā virāgo hoti—
root_text.mn101:26.8: Tassa tassa dukkhanidānassa ajjhupekkhato upekkhaṁ bhāvayato virāgo hoti—
root_text.mn101:26.10: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.
root_text.mn101:27.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn101:27.2: ‘yathāsukhaṁ kho me viharato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
root_text.mn101:27.3: dukkhāya pana me attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn101:27.6: Tassa dukkhāya attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn101:27.7: So na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati.
root_text.mn101:27.9: Yassa hi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu atthāya dukkhāya attānaṁ padaheyya svāssa attho abhinipphanno hoti.
root_text.mn101:27.10: Tasmā na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati.
root_text.mn101:28.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, usukāro tejanaṁ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeti paritāpeti ujuṁ karoti kammaniyaṁ.
root_text.mn101:29.1: Yato kho, bhikkhave, usukārassa tejanaṁ dvīsu alātesu ātāpitaṁ hoti paritāpitaṁ ujuṁ kataṁ kammaniyaṁ, na so taṁ aparena samayena usukāro tejanaṁ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeti paritāpeti ujuṁ karoti kammaniyaṁ.
root_text.mn101:29.3: Yassa hi so, bhikkhave, atthāya usukāro tejanaṁ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeyya paritāpeyya ujuṁ kareyya kammaniyaṁ svāssa attho abhinipphanno hoti.
root_text.mn101:29.4: Tasmā na aparena samayena usukāro tejanaṁ dvīsu alātesu ātāpeti paritāpeti ujuṁ karoti kammaniyaṁ.
root_text.mn101:29.5: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn101:29.6: ‘yathāsukhaṁ kho me viharato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti;
root_text.mn101:29.7: dukkhāya pana me attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn101:29.10: Tassa dukkhāya attānaṁ padahato akusalā dhammā parihāyanti, kusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.
root_text.mn101:29.11: So na aparena samayena dukkhāya attānaṁ padahati.

root_text.mn101:29.15: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.
root_text.mn101:30.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
root_text.mn101:30.2: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
root_text.mn101:30.3: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
root_text.mn101:31.1: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
root_text.mn101:31.2: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
root_text.mn101:31.3: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn101:31.5: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
root_text.mn101:31.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn101:31.7: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya, appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn101:32.1: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṁ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
root_text.mn101:32.2: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
root_text.mn101:32.3: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
root_text.mn101:32.4: Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.
root_text.mn101:32.5: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṁ bhedāya, amutra vā sutvā na imesaṁ akkhātā amūsaṁ bhedāya—iti bhinnānaṁ vā sandhātā sahitānaṁ vā anuppadātā samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn101:32.6: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā hoti.
root_text.mn101:32.7: Samphappalāpaṁ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṁ vācaṁ bhāsitā kālena sāpadesaṁ pariyantavatiṁ atthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.mn101:33.1: So santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn101:33.2: Seyyathāpi nāma pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti sapattabhārova ḍeti;
root_text.mn101:33.3: evameva bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena; so yena yeneva pakkamati samādāyeva pakkamati.
root_text.mn101:33.4: So iminā ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ anavajjasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn101:34.1: So cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn101:34.2: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ cakkhundriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ, cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn101:34.7: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
root_text.mn101:34.8: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn101:34.9: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn101:35.1: So abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
root_text.mn101:36.1: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato
root_text.mn101:36.2: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
root_text.mn101:36.3: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā, ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya, parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
root_text.mn101:37.1: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn101:37.2: Byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn101:37.3: Thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn101:37.4: Uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn101:37.5: Vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
root_text.mn101:38.1: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
root_text.mn101:38.2: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn101:38.3: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.
root_text.mn101:39.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn101:39.2: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.

root_text.mn101:40.2: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.
root_text.mn101:41.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn101:41.2: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.
root_text.mn101:42.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn101:42.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn101:42.3: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.
root_text.mn101:43.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn101:43.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn101:43.3: Evampi, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.
root_text.mn101:44.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn101:44.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
root_text.mn101:44.3: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn101:45.1: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn101:45.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn101:45.4: Evampi kho, bhikkhave, saphalo upakkamo hoti, saphalaṁ padhānaṁ.

translation_text.mn101:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Devadaha.
translation_text.mn101:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn101:2.4: “Mendicants, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn101:2.5: ‘Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.
translation_text.mn101:2.6: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.
translation_text.mn101:2.7: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.’
translation_text.mn101:2.8: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.
translation_text.mn101:3.1: I’ve gone up to the Jain ascetics who say this and said,
translation_text.mn101:3.2: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
translation_text.mn101:4.3: for sure that you existed in the past, and it is not the case that you did not exist?’
translation_text.mn101:4.6: for sure that you did bad deeds in the past?’
translation_text.mn101:4.9: that you did such and such bad deeds?’
translation_text.mn101:4.12: that so much suffering has already been worn away? Or that so much suffering still remains to be worn away? Or that when so much suffering is worn away all suffering will have been worn away?’
translation_text.mn101:4.15: about giving up unskillful qualities in this very life and embracing skillful qualities?’
translation_text.mn101:5.1: ‘So it seems that you don’t know any of these things.
translation_text.mn101:5.7: In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
translation_text.mn101:6.1: Now, supposing you did know these things.
translation_text.mn101:6.7: In that case, it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
translation_text.mn101:7.1: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison,
translation_text.mn101:7.2: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn101:7.3: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
translation_text.mn101:7.4: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,
translation_text.mn101:7.5: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn101:7.7: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn101:7.9: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn101:7.10: They’d apply cauterizing medicine to the wound,
translation_text.mn101:7.11: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn101:7.12: After some time that wound would be healed and the skin regrown. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.
translation_text.mn101:7.14: “Earlier I was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison,
translation_text.mn101:7.15: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
translation_text.mn101:7.16: My friends and colleagues, relatives and kin got a surgeon to treat me.
translation_text.mn101:7.17: At each step, the treatment was painful.
translation_text.mn101:7.25: But these days that wound is healed and the skin regrown. I’m healthy, happy, autonomous, my own master, able to go where I want.”
translation_text.mn101:8.1: In the same way, reverends, if you knew about these things,
translation_text.mn101:8.7: it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
translation_text.mn101:9.1: But since you don’t know any of these things,
translation_text.mn101:9.7: it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.’
translation_text.mn101:10.1: When I said this, those Jain ascetics said to me,
translation_text.mn101:10.2: ‘Reverend, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
translation_text.mn101:10.3: “Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”
translation_text.mn101:10.5: “O reverend Jain ascetics, you have done bad deeds in a past life. Wear them away with these severe and grueling austerities.
translation_text.mn101:10.6: And when in the present you are restrained in body, speech, and mind, you’re not doing any bad deeds for the future.
translation_text.mn101:10.7: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.
translation_text.mn101:10.8: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.”
translation_text.mn101:10.9: We endorse and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.’
translation_text.mn101:11.1: When they said this, I said to them,
translation_text.mn101:11.2: ‘These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways.
translation_text.mn101:11.4: Faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, and acceptance of a view after deliberation.
translation_text.mn101:11.5: These are the five things that can be seen to turn out in two different ways.
translation_text.mn101:11.6: In this case, what faith in your teacher do you have when it comes to the past? What endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation?’
translation_text.mn101:11.7: When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.
translation_text.mn101:12.1: Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics,
translation_text.mn101:12.3: At a time of intense exertion and striving do you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?
translation_text.mn101:12.4: Whereas at a time without intense exertion and striving do you not suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’
translation_text.mn101:12.5: ‘Reverend Gotama, at a time of intense exertion we suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,
translation_text.mn101:13.1: ‘So it seems that only at a time of intense exertion do you suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,
translation_text.mn101:13.3: In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare:
translation_text.mn101:13.4: “Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”
translation_text.mn101:14.1: If at a time of intense exertion you did not suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,
translation_text.mn101:14.2: and if without intense exertion you did experience such feelings,
translation_text.mn101:14.3: it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
translation_text.mn101:15.1: But since this is not the case,
translation_text.mn101:15.3: aren’t you experiencing painful, sharp feelings due only to your own exertion, which out of ignorance, unknowing, and confusion you misconstrue to imply:
translation_text.mn101:15.4: “Everything this individual person experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”?’
translation_text.mn101:15.7: When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.
translation_text.mn101:16.1: Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics,
translation_text.mn101:16.2: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced in this life, can exertion make it be experienced in lives to come?’
translation_text.mn101:16.4: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced in lives to come, can exertion make it be experienced in this life?’
translation_text.mn101:17.1: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced as pleasure, can exertion make it be experienced as pain?’
translation_text.mn101:17.3: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced as pain, can exertion make it be experienced as pleasure?’
translation_text.mn101:18.1: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced when fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when not fully ripened?’
translation_text.mn101:18.3: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced when not fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when fully ripened?’
translation_text.mn101:19.1: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced strongly, can exertion make it be experienced weakly?’
translation_text.mn101:19.3: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced weakly, can exertion make it be experienced strongly?’
translation_text.mn101:20.1: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced, can exertion make it not be experienced?’
translation_text.mn101:20.3: ‘But if a deed is not to be experienced, can exertion make it be experienced?’
translation_text.mn101:21.1: ‘So it seems that exertion cannot change the way deeds are experienced in any of these ways.
translation_text.mn101:21.2: This being so, your exertion and striving are fruitless.’
translation_text.mn101:22.1: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.
translation_text.mn101:22.2: Saying this, the Jain ascetics deserve rebuttal and criticism on ten legitimate grounds.
translation_text.mn101:22.3: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
translation_text.mn101:22.4: clearly the Jains have done bad deeds in the past, since they now experience such intense pain.
translation_text.mn101:22.5: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation,
translation_text.mn101:22.6: clearly the Jains were created by a bad God, since they now experience such intense pain.
translation_text.mn101:22.7: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature,
translation_text.mn101:22.8: clearly the Jains arise from bad circumstances, since they now experience such intense pain.
translation_text.mn101:22.9: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,
translation_text.mn101:22.10: clearly the Jains have been reborn in a bad class, since they now experience such intense pain.
translation_text.mn101:22.11: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in this life,
translation_text.mn101:22.12: clearly the Jains exert themselves badly in this life, since they now experience such intense pain.
translation_text.mn101:22.13: The Jains deserve criticism whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
translation_text.mn101:22.23: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.
translation_text.mn101:22.24: The Jain ascetics who say this deserve rebuttal and criticism on these ten legitimate grounds.
translation_text.mn101:22.25: That’s how exertion and striving is fruitless.
translation_text.mn101:23.1: And how is exertion and striving fruitful?
translation_text.mn101:23.2: It’s when a mendicant does not bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t forsake legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure.
translation_text.mn101:23.4: ‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’
translation_text.mn101:23.5: So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate.
translation_text.mn101:23.7: Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering,
translation_text.mn101:23.8: and so that suffering is worn away.
translation_text.mn101:23.9: Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering,
translation_text.mn101:23.10: and so that suffering is worn away.
translation_text.mn101:24.1: Suppose a man is in love with a woman, full of intense desire and lust.
translation_text.mn101:24.2: Then he sees her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.
translation_text.mn101:24.4: Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”
translation_text.mn101:24.7: Because that man is in love with that woman, full of intense desire and lust.”
translation_text.mn101:25.2: ‘I’m in love with that woman, full of intense desire and lust.
translation_text.mn101:25.3: When I saw her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing, it gave rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for me.
translation_text.mn101:25.4: Why don’t I give up that desire and lust for that woman?’
translation_text.mn101:25.6: Some time later he sees her again standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.
translation_text.mn101:25.8: Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”
translation_text.mn101:25.11: Because he no longer desires that woman.”
translation_text.mn101:26.1: “In the same way, a mendicant does not bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t forsake legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure.
translation_text.mn101:26.3: ‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’
translation_text.mn101:26.4: So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate.
translation_text.mn101:26.6: Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering,
translation_text.mn101:26.7: and so that suffering is worn away.
translation_text.mn101:26.8: Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering,
translation_text.mn101:26.9: and so that suffering is worn away.
translation_text.mn101:26.10: That’s how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:27.2: ‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn101:27.3: But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn101:27.6: and as they do so unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn101:27.7: After some time, they no longer strive painfully.
translation_text.mn101:27.9: Because they have accomplished the goal for which they strived painfully.
translation_text.mn101:28.1: Suppose an arrowsmith was heating an arrow shaft between two firebrands, making it straight and fit for use.
translation_text.mn101:29.1: After it’s been made straight and fit for use, they’d no longer heat it to make it straight and fit for use.
translation_text.mn101:29.3: Because they have accomplished the goal for which they heated it.
translation_text.mn101:29.5: In the same way, a mendicant reflects:
translation_text.mn101:29.6: ‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.
translation_text.mn101:29.7: But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.
translation_text.mn101:29.14: After some time, they no longer strive painfully.
translation_text.mn101:29.15: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:30.1: Furthermore, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
translation_text.mn101:30.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn101:30.3: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn101:31.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
translation_text.mn101:31.2: They gain faith in the Realized One,
translation_text.mn101:31.4: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn101:31.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn101:31.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn101:31.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn101:32.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
translation_text.mn101:32.2: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
translation_text.mn101:32.3: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
translation_text.mn101:32.4: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
translation_text.mn101:32.5: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
translation_text.mn101:32.6: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
translation_text.mn101:32.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
translation_text.mn101:32.8: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
translation_text.mn101:32.9: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
translation_text.mn101:32.10: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
translation_text.mn101:32.11: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
translation_text.mn101:32.12: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
translation_text.mn101:32.13: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
translation_text.mn101:32.22: They refrain from running errands and messages;
translation_text.mn101:32.26: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
translation_text.mn101:33.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn101:33.2: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
translation_text.mn101:33.3: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
translation_text.mn101:33.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
translation_text.mn101:34.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn101:34.2: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn101:34.3: When they hear a sound with their ears …
translation_text.mn101:34.4: When they smell an odor with their nose …
translation_text.mn101:34.5: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
translation_text.mn101:34.6: When they feel a touch with their body …
translation_text.mn101:34.7: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
translation_text.mn101:34.8: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
translation_text.mn101:34.9: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
translation_text.mn101:35.1: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
translation_text.mn101:36.1: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
translation_text.mn101:36.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.mn101:36.3: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
translation_text.mn101:37.1: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
translation_text.mn101:37.2: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
translation_text.mn101:37.3: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
translation_text.mn101:37.4: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
translation_text.mn101:37.5: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
translation_text.mn101:38.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn101:38.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn101:38.3: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:39.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn101:39.2: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:40.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn101:40.2: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:41.1: Furthermore, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn101:41.2: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:42.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn101:42.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn101:42.3: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:43.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn101:43.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understood how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn101:43.3: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:44.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn101:44.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn101:44.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn101:45.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn101:45.2: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn101:45.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn101:45.4: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
translation_text.mn101:46.1: Such is the doctrine of the Realized One.
translation_text.mn101:46.2: Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on ten legitimate grounds.
translation_text.mn101:46.3: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
translation_text.mn101:46.4: clearly the Realized One has done good deeds in the past, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
translation_text.mn101:46.5: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation,
translation_text.mn101:46.6: clearly the Realized One was created by a good God, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
translation_text.mn101:46.7: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature,
translation_text.mn101:46.8: clearly the Realized One arises from good circumstances, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
translation_text.mn101:46.9: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,
translation_text.mn101:46.10: clearly the Realized One was reborn in a good class, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
translation_text.mn101:46.11: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in this life,
translation_text.mn101:46.12: clearly the Realized One exerts himself well in this life, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
translation_text.mn101:46.13: The Realized One deserves praise whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
translation_text.mn101:46.23: Such is the doctrine of the Realized One.
translation_text.mn101:46.24: Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on these ten legitimate grounds.”
translation_text.mn101:46.25: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn101:46.26: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
